comments.commentBody: @Jasoturner: Many  commenters lack worldliness, were not held to a high standard in college,and appear unwilling to write a comment that has substance, no se ofenda. When I wrote about conversations with Robert Martel, "chouan de la Mitidja" on his farm in Chebli over glasses of homemade calvados,not one person wrote a rejoinder. When I wrote that cutting 37 percent of State's budget was not such a bad idea because, in my informed view,many diplomats never bothered to learn indigenous languages of countries to which they were assigned,and were superfluous, not one person replied to negate the charge. Does that not show a lack of worldliness,a lack of intellectual curiosity?Comments column should be characterized by a lively give and take between those with opposing ideologies, but instead seems to be only an opportunity to vent one's spleen against Trump, make vicious allegations lacking specificity.

I can't forget Trump's outrageous, but very telling, statement he made when campaigning: "I could stand in the middle of Fifth Avenue and shoot somebody and I wouldn't lose any voters"

I think President Boated Ego & our gargantuan Liar-in-Chief is so arrogant and full of himself that, super salesman that he thinks he is, he truly believes can talk his way out of this Trump-Russian imbroglio--just like he always does with his wheeling and dealings that are often unethical, many times illegal, and too often do serious damage to any people involved.

But if Grandma is correct, "The truth will win out in the long run"--probably with no help from the stonewalling, lackey Republicans--and the Trump presidency will implode like one of those Macy's Thanksgiving Day hot-air balloons. And Trump may just take the Republican Party with him, if the self-proclaimed patriotic Republicans block a full-scale, fair investigation of the Trump-Russian connection.

Trump's Russia-gate is far more serious than Watergate, but not unlike Reagan's Iran-Contra-gate and Cheney-Bush's really, really Big LIe that put us in a "preemptive" war in Iraq.

Frankly, I think it will be the press, not the Republicans, that will finally get to the bottom of Trump's flagrant lies, misdoings and dangerous misdeeds. No wonder Trump is trying so hard to besmirch and demean the press.

Trump-Russia-gate is a very important battle between demagogue vs. democracy. The question is which side will citizens take?
I have a couple buckets of bituminous roof coating and a sack of goose feathers in my shed
I agree.... this needs much more exposure NYT"s are you game?

If the (so-called) president of the US lies, and the top law enforcement officer of the US, the attorney general, lies... WHY SHOULD ANYONE TELL THE TRUTH?

Why should any of us obey the laws? That's apparently only for suckers.

Why should any of us pay our taxes? That's only for losers.

If even a sizable minority of citizens started behaving like the S-C POTUS and his gang of flunkies, there would be a breakdown in civil society.

So how can we possibly tolerate this at the top? We can't. Investigate, fire and impeach!

To tito perdue.
Because he doesn't know he could/would be impeached.
The country will luck out.
It is only a question of how and when.
Better get some salve on that dum-dum wound, Tito.
I was confused is a thrid grader excuse -- it works for them.

They absolutely can get away with it as long as people do not bother to get out and vote. This is all about elections- and who comes out to vote and who doesn't. The electoral college is one thing- but the Dems also lost Congress and most races on the state level- which is why we have such rampant corruption at every level.
But ... but ... Hillary!

You seem to forget that he was meeting with him AFTER the news of the Russian hacking broke.  Such a story might have made you and be a bit cautious to be in the same room, perhaps with your i-phone operating.  But, no, Sessions invites him to his Senate office.  Why?  He should have been a persona non gratia at that point.  Then why lie about it if it were really just an innocent chat?  Alas, the more the stick stirs, the ranker the smell.  What possible purpose does the AG have in meeting with a Russian diplomat?  To discuss human rights?  Wouldn't that have been a laugh.

The late Sen Kennedy also tried to arrange a National television interview with the then Russian Ambassador to falsely implicate Reagan during the election. He was caught and it never happened and of course he denied it sort of like Chapaquidic. I wouldn't use his name as his support for the argument.

Hey, Gail,

Start calling Sessions the "Dixie Pixie"!

Fairness anyone?  Sitting at a whole table of both Democrats and Republicans together with Russian diplomats is not the same as a one-on-one meetings that you deny having.  I would imagine that almost every Senator has met in public with all kinds of foreign ambassadors.  So she didn't "meet" with him in the same way that Sessions did, and that was all she was saying.  So yes, a little fairness would be nice.

Also, remember that during the convention, the GOP platform was revised to NOT support arming of the Ukrainian dissidents. We need to understand if the release of the Wikileaks documents was a quid pro quo for withdrawing support for the Ukrainian dissidents.

If you believe:
- Trump paid ladies of the night to relieve themselves in the bed where the Obama's slept while he was watching them doing it as an act of disrespect;
- or if the degenerate in our White House enjoyed having it done on him,
- or if we are both correct and Trump paid ladies of the night relieve themselves on him while in the bed where the Obama's had slept,
it does not matter.

In any of these scenarios Trump would be out of the White House if a video of ANY of these possibilities surfaces. This means given Trump's repeated calls to go easy on Putin and going as far as making excuses for Putin when people accused that Putin is a killer by saying WE ALL DO KILLINGS!!! I personally would like to go to the bottom of it if a Trump appointee is caught lying about having talked to Russian agents as Sessions was caught to have done.

The leadership of the Trump administration and of the GOP is full of admirers of Ronald Reagan.

What I learned from Ronald Reagan is the value of plausible deniability. It's ok as long as no one catches you *and* can prove it.

As a member of the bar for over 40 years, I can honestly say that, if I'd done what Sessions did (not only under-oath lies about his Russia connection, but also about his litigation experience), I'd be in prison right now.

No-brainer.

He must go.

...and we tax payers actually pay this Sessions guy?....plus great cushy benefits too? When will the American people use their power, these elected people are supposed to serve us, "servants"....they should not be pursuing their own greed driven personal power agendas at our expense while they are on our dime...we are their employers after all and Sessions gets better benefits then most Americans in the public sector. This is not acceptable and  as an American I feel embarrassed by these GOP guys in the eyes of the world.

J Sutton writes: "It looks like Jeff Sessions has just proven that a top government official can lie, double down on that lie, and continue to expand a bald-faced lie under oath and actually get away with it. He paves the path for many more shameless liars to gain success and fame through their dishonesty."

He didn't pave that path - Trump's election did.

Isn't it beyond any shade of doubt that he has had financial dealings with the Russians? His own sons have bragged about the money coming in from there. The only open question is how badly he is in debt to foreign operatives - and everything happening (or not happening, ie revealing tax returns) suggests that the debt is very, very deep.

@scippy, you offer no rationale for Uber's tactics. It's just a Trumpian type of response: arguing 8-year olds. And remember, as salaries decline, Americans have to live with the consequences. There isn't much room in the top 1%. But Uber wants to be über alles which evokes a disturbing image.
We need a rational way to address workers' compensation.

Has anyone considered diplomacy and engagement as the best of all possible options to minimize the chance for nuclear annihilation of the planet?  Does our government expect it can keep nations from advancing their understanding and learning of advanced scientific and engineering technology?

Paul, that is precisely why DPRK wants nuclear threat. Leverage for trade; food. But it's doubling down on terror. This is one of the few scenarios where "regime change," is not simply a national security interest, but a pan global security interest because targeting notwithstanding it is the distance those rockets can travel with a warhead that makes it a force multiplier; global threat.  Kim Jong-un is proving to be more unstable and bellicose than most intelligence officials could have anticipated. He's running away with the dish and the spoon and it would be an of preservation to see to his elimination. Sorry to say, but proved.
Not likely to happen, Mr. Cohen, because the president would then be called "weak" by his adversaries.

Both South Korean and the US have tried the diplomatic track with North Korea many times.  The North has broken every agreement they have ever signed Diplomacy with North Korea is a pipe dream unless it comes forcefully from China.

Let me tell you how Scott Walker and his people "stood strong" in the recall election against those who exercised their citizenship and legal rights to publicly support unions in Wisconsin.

Walker and company assassinated the character of those who opposed him and his corrupt crew. They accomplished this by creating an internet website using the names of those who signed the recall petition, then any search done on that person's name comes up with the words "sex offender registry", which is a total lie, designed to destroy the reputation of everyone who supported collective bargaining and unions. These are the kind of people running Scott Walker's Wisconsin.

Worth keeping mind as you read this is that Governor Walker is not exactly the sharpest tool in the shed. His Transportation Department, one of the more significant departments at the state level, cannot properly estimate costs for major projects within a factor of three. His Economic Development department doesn't function, and one of the main (only?) engines of economic development in Wisconsin, the University system, is under constant attack by him and his like-minded legislature.

For everyone else the formula is simple: read Walker's words and do pretty much the opposite. Sadly for the people of Wisconsin his years of dumbing down the state seem to be showing a cumulative effect.
